stocks.name: Enbridge Inc.
stocks.thesis: Record 2025 EBITDA ($20B, +7%), 31 consecutive dividend raises, $39B secured backlog growing at 5%/year post-2026. Forward P/DCF of ~11.9x sits at the LOW end of regulated infrastructure's 12–16x historical range — earnings have grown into the price premium. Trump energy policy is a direct tailwind for ENB's massive US natural gas network. Price near ATH but valuation justified by fundamentals; add aggressively on any pullback to $65–67 CAD.
stocks.risks: D/EBITDA at 4.8x — manageable but limited buffer. Ongoing equity dilution from $39B growth capex. No price margin of safety at near-ATH levels — best entry $65–67 CAD for a 5.8–6.0% yield.

stocks.name: Bank of Nova Scotia
stocks.thesis: Q1 2026 earnings released Feb 24: $2.3B net income vs $993M year ago (+132% YoY) — massive beat. Pacific Alliance diversification (LatAm) is contrarian value play. At ~$104 CAD, trading above 200-day MA with fresh earnings catalyst. Add on pullback to $98–101 CAD for yield ~4.4–4.5%.
stocks.risks: Higher international credit exposure (LatAm) vs RY/TD creates more earnings volatility across credit cycles. Not a core sleep-at-night holding at full weight.

stocks.name: Nebius Group N.V.
stocks.thesis: European AI cloud infrastructure company (formerly Yandex NV) building GPU clusters to compete with AWS/Azure for AI workloads. Up 430%+ from 52-wk low, but analysts still see 45%+ upside to avg target of $143-155. Targets 40% adjusted EBITDA margins by 2026. This is a growth play, not a dividend play.
stocks.risks: No dividend. Highly volatile — ranged from $18 to $141 in 52 weeks. AI infrastructure buildout is massively capex-intensive. Sentiment-driven stock that can drop 30%+ quickly.

stocks.name: TELUS Corporation
stocks.thesis: 5G capex tapering driving FCF surge — record $2.2B FCF in 2025, up 11% YoY with 10%+ CAGR guided through 2028. Committed to 3-8% annual dividend increases from 2026 through 2028. A 9% yield with dividend growth in a telecom with hard infrastructure moat.
stocks.risks: High debt load; TELUS International drag and CRTC regulatory risk remain. Dividend growth lower end of 3-8% range if macro deteriorates.

stocks.name: Allied Properties REIT
stocks.thesis: Office REIT trading near 52-week lows, down 57% from 52-week high. Dividend was cut from C$0.15/month to C$0.06/month but forward yield still ~7.5% at current price. Analyst consensus target C$14.33 implies +48% upside. Distressed but not dead — high-quality urban office assets in major Canadian cities.
stocks.risks: DISTRESSED. Negative EPS (-$4.10). Office sector under structural WFH pressure. Dividend was already cut once — another cut possible. Not suitable as a core dividend holding — speculative recovery play only.

stocks.name: Canadian Natural Resources
stocks.thesis: Canada's largest oil sands producer with 24 consecutive years of dividend growth. $6.3B 2026 capex budget targeting high-return oil sands growth. Long-life, low-decline assets mean dividends are structurally sustainable across oil price cycles. Analyst avg target implies ~14% upside.
stocks.risks: Oil price exposure — dividend safety depends on WTI staying above ~$50. Tariff/trade war impacts on Canadian energy exports. Not for the risk-averse.

stocks.name: ARC Resources
stocks.thesis: Premier Montney natural gas producer with exceptional dividend growth — 10x since 2020 including +11% raise announced with Q3 2025 results. Revenue up 19% and earnings up 13% in FY2025. LNG Canada export tailwind provides multi-year earnings catalyst. Analyst target C$31.96 = +30% upside.
stocks.risks: Nat gas commodity price exposure and tariff/trade war impacts on Canadian energy exports.

stocks.name: Cogeco Communications
stocks.thesis: Deeply mispriced cable/internet operator trading at 9.4x P/E vs sector average of 15x, with P/B below 1.0 and Alpha Spread intrinsic value of $122.93 — implying 44% undervaluation. S&P and Moody's improved credit outlooks Jan 2026; Morningstar 5-star rated.
stocks.risks: Cord-cutting structural headwind with revenue declining ~4% YoY, and $4.64B debt at 3.24x EBITDA.

stocks.name: Enghouse Systems
stocks.thesis: Canadian B2B software acquirer down 48% from 52-week high. $269M cash, zero debt. Serial acquisition model (41 deals since 1984). Forward P/E 10.2x vs software sector 20-30x. All three buy-low signals fire. Next earnings March 5.
stocks.risks: 89% payout ratio — dividend at risk if earnings decline further. Revenue flat/declining. Technically in downtrend.

stocks.name: Alaris Equity Partners
stocks.thesis: Royalty income trust generating stable cash flows from private mid-market businesses, with an 8.82% dividend raise in January 2026. Crossed the 200-day moving average signalling improving momentum.
stocks.risks: Currently trading ABOVE all historical averages — not a screaming value; better entry would be around $20.

stocks.name: RioCan REIT
stocks.thesis: Grocery-anchored retail REIT trading at 12x forward FFO vs 15x long-term historical average — a 20% valuation discount implying ~$24.40 fair value (25% upside). Three analyst target upgrades in four days from National Bank, CIBC, and BMO; 19M unit buyback underway.
stocks.risks: Rate-sensitive retail REIT; Canadian consumer spending slowdown and historical dividend cut in COVID create psychological overhang.

stocks.name: BCE Inc.
stocks.thesis: ⚠️ DIVIDEND CUT — BCE announced a cut from $3.99 to $1.75/share (56% reduction) alongside restructuring and job reductions. The investment thesis as a dividend compounder is broken until management demonstrates FCF recovery.
stocks.risks: Dividend cut is structural, not tactical. Avoid until there is evidence of FCF stabilization and a credible path back to dividend growth.

stocks.name: Fortis Inc.
stocks.thesis: 52 consecutive years of dividend increases — the longest streak in Canada. $28.8B capex plan drives 7% annual rate base growth through 2030, supporting 4-6% dividend growth guidance. Rate-cut tailwind has re-rated the stock from 2024 lows (~$61) to current ATH (~$78); at P/E ~16x and 3.2% yield the stock is fairly valued, but 4% above average analyst consensus. Wait for a dip to $68-72 CAD (3.5-3.7% yield) for ideal entry.
stocks.risks: No margin of safety at ATH — any BoC rate pause or reversal hits utilities hard and fast; stock is 4% above average analyst target of $74.97 CAD.

stocks.name: Shopify Inc.
stocks.thesis: Canadian tech flagship. Down 22% in 6 weeks from $168.45 (Jan 6 high) — macro/tariff fears creating potential entry. Analyst consensus Buy, avg target ~$162 USD (~$232 CAD) = 77% upside from current. Commerce infrastructure story intact: Payments, Capital, Markets, B2B growing. No dividend — pure growth play. Best entry zone $115-125 CAD if it pulls back further.
stocks.risks: No dividend, elevated valuation even post-selloff (fwd P/E still 50x+). Revenue growth decelerating from hypergrowth era. Macro sensitivity. Tariff/trade war rhetoric hurts e-commerce sentiment.

stocks.name: Brookfield Asset Management Ltd.
stocks.thesis: World-class alternative asset manager with $1T+ AUM across infra, renewable energy, real estate, private equity, credit. Record 2025 results announced Feb 27. 15% dividend increase announced same day. Analyst consensus target ~$63.94 USD (~$91 CAD) = 27% upside from current CAD price. Fee-related earnings growing 20%+ annually. Long-duration compounding machine with a growing income stream. Best alternative asset manager on TSX.
stocks.risks: Payout ratio 115%+ in USD terms — dividend covered by fee-related earnings but optics are weak. Rate sensitivity (AUM growth slows when rate environment hurts fundraising). Complex structure — BAM vs BN (Brookfield Corp) can be confusing.

stocks.name: iShares S&P/TSX Composite High Dividend Index ETF
stocks.thesis: iShares high-dividend Canadian equity ETF — 75 holdings across energy, financials, utilities, REITs. Monthly distributions ($0.112/month = ~$1.34/yr). Ex-div Feb 24, 2026. Low-cost passive income — simple, diversified Canadian dividend exposure in one ticker. Good core income holding for TFSA/RRSP. Near 52wk high so not a screaming entry — add on dips below $34.
stocks.risks: Near 52wk high — limited short-term upside. Heavy energy and financials weighting = sector concentration. Passive instrument won't avoid dividend cuts within holdings (e.g. BCE-type situations). MER small but not zero.

stocks.name: iShares Core Growth ETF Portfolio
stocks.thesis: One-ticker diversified growth portfolio — 80% global equities / 20% bonds. MER 0.17% (just reduced from 0.18% Dec 2025). Holds iShares equity and bond ETFs across global markets. Simple, low-cost, automatic rebalancing. Ideal for TFSA growth allocation — set-and-forget core holding. Not a dividend story — total return play.
stocks.risks: Not a dividend vehicle (small distributions). 20% bond allocation drags return vs pure equity in bull markets. Currency exposure to USD/global. Near 52wk high.

stocks.name: Advanced Micro Devices CDR (CAD Hedged)
stocks.thesis: CDR (Canadian Depositary Receipt) of AMD — CAD-hedged exposure to Advanced Micro Devices without USD currency risk. AMD US is a top AI/data centre chip play alongside NVIDIA. MI300X GPU gaining traction in hyperscaler AI workloads. Forward P/E ~29x (reasonable for AI semis). CDR ratio means each unit represents a fraction of one AMD share. Analyst consensus targets imply significant upside on AI infrastructure build-out. NOTE: Verify current CDR price — approximate entry used here.
stocks.risks: No dividend. High volatility (AI hype cycle). NVIDIA dominates GPU market — AMD is the #2 play. CDR liquidity lower than NASDAQ AMD. AI capex could compress if hyperscaler spending slows. Price is approximate — verify before buying.

stocks.name: Tourmaline Oil Corp.
stocks.thesis: Canada's largest natural gas producer. Base dividend + special dividends = ~$3.55/yr (~5.6% at current price). Monthly distributions. Real tailwinds: LNG Canada coming online, rising US nat gas demand, AI data centre electricity demand. Just crossed its 200-day MA ($62.67) — improving momentum. Earnings Mar 11, 2026. Best entry below $58-60 CAD for a 6%+ yield and meaningful upside. Nat gas is the clean energy bridge fuel — TOU is the dominant Canadian play.
stocks.risks: Special dividends variable — base dividend alone is ~2.5%, so yield depends on commodity prices and cash flow. Natural gas price is cyclical. If nat gas prices drop, specials get cut first. Current price near short-term resistance.

stocks.name: TC Energy Corporation
stocks.thesis: Pure-play natural gas infrastructure — 93,000 km of pipelines across Canada, US, Mexico. Spun off South Bow (liquids) in 2024 to focus on nat gas. $3.51/yr dividend, 5.6% yield. Regulated/contracted revenues = steady cashflow. Trump energy policy is a tailwind for continental nat gas. Goldman Sachs raised target to $53 USD ($75 CAD) Feb 18. Analyst consensus target CAD$82. DO NOT BUY AT ATH — wait for pullback to $75-78 CAD where yield opens to ~4.5%+ and upside reappears.
stocks.risks: Payout ratio 106% — dividend slightly stretched vs free cash flow. Debt/equity 2.23 — highly levered. Currently at ALL-TIME HIGH ($86.97 on Feb 13) and above analyst consensus. Buying here = chasing. Keystone XL history shows regulatory/political risk. Wait for the entry.

stocks.name: iShares Core S&P/TSX Capped Composite Index ETF
stocks.thesis: Broadest TSX index exposure — ~240 Canadian stocks, heavily weighted to financials and energy. MER 0.05% (cheapest broad Canadian index ETF). The go-to vehicle for passive TSX exposure in a TFSA. TSX composite just closed at an ALL-TIME HIGH of 33,818 on Feb 21, 2026 — XIC is near ATH at $54. Best entry below $46 (~15% correction). Long-term: Canadian equities are cheap vs S&P 500 on P/E, commodity-backed, and benefit from a weaker CAD. Buy at the right price.
stocks.risks: At ATH — buying now means buying at peak. Heavy financials + energy exposure = Canada-specific concentration risk. USD/CAD moves affect international comparisons. Low yield (2.3%) vs picking individual dividend stocks.

stocks.name: iShares S&P/TSX 60 Index ETF
stocks.thesis: Canada's most liquid ETF — tracks the S&P/TSX 60 (top 60 TSX companies). $21B in assets. More concentrated than XIC but very tradeable. Same core thesis as XIC: excellent long-term hold, terrible entry at ATH. MER 0.15% (3x higher than XIC — prefer XIC for buy-and-hold). Ex-div was today Feb 24 ($0.277/unit). Best entry below $42.
stocks.risks: More concentrated than XIC (60 vs 240 stocks). Higher MER than XIC. At 52-week high — near ATH. XIC is generally superior for long-term buy-and-hold.

stocks.name: Suncor Energy Inc.
stocks.thesis: Canada's premier integrated oil sands company — upstream production, downstream refining, and Petro-Canada retail. Warren Buffett owned it (Berkshire). Aggressive buyback program (billions annually). Analyst avg target ~$48.86 — currently slightly above. Strong FCF generator at $70+ WTI. Wait for pullback below $42-44 to get meaningful upside + 3.5%+ yield.
stocks.risks: Currently trading above analyst consensus target. Oil price sensitive — WTI below $60 compresses margins hard. Oilsands have high breakeven vs shale. Buybacks slow when oil prices drop.

stocks.name: Pembina Pipeline Corporation
stocks.thesis: Western Canadian midstream infrastructure — 18,000 km of pipelines, NGL fractionation, gas processing. Monthly dividends (5.25% yield). Take-or-pay contracts = highly predictable cashflow. One of the most reliable dividend payers on the TSX. Analyst target $58-60 — currently AT the ceiling. Wait for pullback to $52-54 where yield opens to 6%+ and upside returns.
stocks.risks: At analyst consensus ceiling right now. Monthly dividends are attractive but yield compression likely near ATH. Commodity-adjacent despite fee-based model. Acquisition of Alliance/Aux Sable added leverage.

stocks.name: Cenovus Energy Inc.
stocks.thesis: Integrated oil sands + refining + US downstream (acquired Husky). Second-largest Canadian oil company. RBC raised target to C$32 (Outperform) Feb 20. Analyst avg target ~$29-31 CAD. Was at $14.48 eight months ago — has nearly doubled. Variable dividend component means payout grows with oil prices. Best entry below $24 where upside to $32 target = 33%+ plus yield.
stocks.risks: At analyst consensus now. Low base yield (2.5%). Took on significant debt with Husky acquisition — balance sheet still healing. Oil price dependent. Refining margins volatile.

stocks.name: Dollarama Inc.
stocks.thesis: Canada's dominant discount retailer — 1,500+ stores, recession-proof model (foot traffic INCREASES in downturns), 32% EBITDA margins, Q3 revenue +22.4% YoY. Expanding internationally via Dollarcity (Latin America). Analyst avg target C$211-216 = ~10-12% upside from current $192. High estimate C$235. Payout ratio only 9.5% — almost all earnings reinvested. NOT a dividend play (0.21% yield). Pure total return/growth story. Best entry below $170-175 (~15-20% discount to current, meaningful upside to targets).
stocks.risks: Effectively zero dividend — not for income investors. Premium valuation (fwd P/E ~30x). Tariff risk on imported goods (most products sourced from China). FX exposure on Dollarcity earnings. Consumer spending slowdown could compress same-store sales growth.
